byline.original: By MICHAEL CORKERY and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

abstract: Many companies, churches, schools and other organizations are requiring secular disputes like financial fraud and wrongful death be resolved through religious arbitration, which is not bound by state or federal law; process is seen as way to honor a set of beliefs, but some legal experts say it can be often used by a group to control legal outcomes (Series: Beware the Fine Print).
lead_paragraph: Organizations can compel their customers and employees to resolve disputes in arbitration proceedings bound not by state or federal law, but by religious edict.

headline.main: In Religious Arbitration, Scripture Is the Rule of Law
headline.content_kicker: Beware the Fine Print | Part III
headline.print_headline: When Scripture Is the Rule of Law
